metadata.title: Fetal Alcohol Syndrome  Communication Disorders
synonyms: fetal alcohol syndrome disorder (fasd): communication disorders
fetal alcohol syndrome disorder (fasd): speech therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Central nervous system (CNS), facial features; skeleton; heart
description: Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) is an umbrella term that describes the range of effects that can occur in an individual whose mother drank alcohol during pregnancy.(29) These effects might include physical, mental, behavioral, or learning impairments. The term FASD is not intended for use as a clinical diagnosis. Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is the most severe end of the FASD spectrum, in which a fetus or newborn is exposed to alcohol and subsequently exhibits a pattern of abnormal facial features and impaired development of the brain/central nervous system (CNS).(4,6) The other diagnostic terms under the umbrella of FASD are partial fetal alcohol syndrome (PFAS) and neurobehavioral disorder associated with prenatal alcohol exposure (ND-PAE)(30)

ICD-10 codes.P04.3: fetus and newborn affected by maternal use of alcohol
ICD-10 codes.Q86.0: fetal alcohol syndrome (dysmorphic) (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

Motor Speech G-code set.G8999: Motor speech functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Motor Speech G-code set.G9186: Motor speech functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Motor Speech G-code set.G9158: Motor speech functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/ end of reporting on limitation

Spoken Language Comprehension G-code set.G9160: Spoken language comprehension functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Spoken Language Comprehension G-code set.G9161: Spoken language comprehension functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

Spoken Language Expressive G-code set.G9163: Spoken language expression functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Spoken Language Expressive G-code set.G9164: Spoken language expression functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

Attention G-code set.G9166: Attention functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Attention G-code set.G9167: Attention functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9174: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9175: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9176: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. Early-intervention  services will be important for consultative and therapeutic intervention
presentation signs and symptoms: Individuals with FAS will present with neurological and physical symptoms

Neurological deficits include: –intellectual disability; worse for children with a higher exposure to alcohol(13,14,18) –attention deficits, specifically for encoding or holding information while performing a mental operation and shifting, or the ability to change focus from one stimulus to another.(2,13,14,18) Also, children with FAS perform poorly when required to attend to visual versus auditory information.(14) Overall, children with FAS have greater difficulty processing complex information compared to peers who are typically developing(14)  –impaired executive functioning specifically for working memory and response inhibition; becomes worse as task complexity increases(14) –difficulty performing mathematical computations or processing numbers(2,10,13,15) –language deficits in the areas of naming, grammar comprehension, and pragmatics.(14) However, these deficits might be closely associated with cognitive deficits such as working memory and self-regulation(14) –visual perception integration (e.g., tasks involving clock drawing or copying tasks)(14,25,26) –learning and memory deficits(2,7,13,14,15,22,26,42) –hyperactivity(14) –behavioral and adaptive difficulties, including impulsivity, memory deficits, and decreased social interaction skills(12,13,26) –infant withdrawal (observed in infants with known high prenatal exposure to alcohol) and emotional disturbances(36) –increased incidence of ear infections due to underdeveloped audiological systems; deficits in hearing, including conductive or sensory neural hearing loss and/or central auditory processing disorder(10,25)
Facial characteristics include: –facial dysmorphia(7,14,23) –short palpebral fissures(29) –small, flat nasal bridge(7) –flat/smooth philtrum(29) –small teeth(7) –smooth, thin upper lip(7)

Physical symptoms include: –microcephaly (decreased head circumference)(7) –growth deficiency(45) –delayed fine and gross motor development(7,14,23) –decreased joint mobility(7) –cardiac abnormalities(7,23) –central nervous system dysfunction(7,14,23) –skeletal abnormalities(7,23) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Children with FAS are at increased risk for abuse. Studies indicate children with FAS are two to three times more likely to have been abused physically, emotionally, or sexually.(10) Children with FAS are often raised by parents with alcohol abuse problems or are placed in foster care; additional environmental risks and adaptation problems will likely be present(17)

Children with FAS sometimes present as excessively affectionate. They often have difficulty distinguishing familiar people from unfamiliar people and enjoy physical touch, which causes concern for physical safety.(17) Always include the child’s parent or legal guardian during the assessment process
Consideration of the child’s cultural background must be established when evaluating speech, language, and cognition

Due to the wide range of deficits children with FAS exhibit, speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) must collaborate with many disciplines to best evaluate and treat children with FAS. Specifically, children with FAS often demonstrate decreased adaptive skills that impact their ability to participate and function in society.(8,12) Consultation with the following specialties will be critical to identify a need for further intervention as soon as possible: neuropsychology, physical therapy, occupational therapy, pediatrics, social work, special education services, health and human service departments, and departments of justice and legal advocacy(10)

causes: FAS is the result of alcohol ingested by the mother that is then passed on to a fetus or newborn. Alcohol is transferredfrom the mother to the placenta, impacting the growth of fetal cells and organs. For a newborn baby, alcohol is transmittedthrough breast milk.(7) The United States Department of Health and Human Services labels alcohol as a teratogen (i.e.,something that causes developmental disabilities) and has stated that no amount of alcohol is considered safe for a fetus ornewborn(47)
pathogenesis: FAS occurs due to alcohol ingestion by the mother. Alcohol is a toxin that is transferred through the placenta and results incell death and neuronal damage to the developing fetus
risk factors: Consumption of alcohol during pregnancy(4,7,29,31)–In a study conducted in the United States with 216 first graders, researchers found that mothers of children who hadFASD reported consuming significantly more alcoholic drinks during the three months prior to pregnancy than did themothers of children without FASD(31)–In the same study of 216 first graders, researchers found that the mothers of children with FASD also reported thattheir husbands/partners consumed significantly more drinks per day during pregnancy as well as more (approachingsignificance) paternal binge drinking than did the mothers of children without FASD(31)
Presence of the maternal ADH1B*3  allele seems to provide some level of protection to the fetus from prenatal alcoholexposure(11)

Authors of a systematic review of 15 articles on maternal factors related to development of FAS reported the followingmaternal characteristics as risk factors for FAS: older age, lower educational level, family members with a history ofalcohol abuse, minimal prenatal care, and a more severe pattern of alcohol consumption in general, as well as duringpregnancy(32)

In the abovementioned study conducted in the United States with 216 first graders, researchers found that mothers ofchildren who had FASD in this sample reported the recognition of their pregnancy further into gestation than did mothersof children without FASD(31)

overall contraindications precautions: See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Children with FAS are at increased risk for abuse. Studies indicate children with FAS are two to three times more likely to have been abused physically, emotionally, or sexually.(10) Children with FAS are often raised by parents with alcohol abuse problems or are placed in foster care; additional environmental risks and adaptation problems will likely be present(17)

Children with FAS sometimes present as excessively affectionate. They often have difficulty distinguishing familiar people from unfamiliar people and enjoy physical touch, which causes concern for physical safety.(17) Always include the child’s parent or legal guardian during the assessment process
Consideration of the child’s cultural background must be established when evaluating speech, language, and cognition

Due to the wide range of deficits children with FAS exhibit, speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) must collaborate with many disciplines to best evaluate and treat children with FAS. Specifically, children with FAS often demonstrate decreased adaptive skills that impact their ability to participate and function in society.(8,12) Consultation with the following specialties will be critical to identify a need for further intervention as soon as possible: neuropsychology, physical therapy, occupational therapy, pediatrics, social work, special education services, health and human service departments, and departments of justice and legal advocacy(10)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Determine when the diagnosis of FAS was made. Review history from the pediatrician. Diagnosis of FAS is often delayed as it is not well understood or recognized in children with developmental disability.(35) In many cases, children with FAS are initially given other diagnoses (e.g., attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, sensory processing disorder, fine motor delay), but the underlying cause, FAS, is not identified until much later.(35) Any child with a developmental delay with known prenatal alcohol exposure should be referred for a full diagnostic evaluation for FASD(39) -Document ages of developmental milestones -At what age did the child begin producing words, cooing, babbling? Language milestones are often delayed in children with FAS -When did the child start to name objects, people? -When did the child begin to put two words together? -How intelligible is the child’s speech? -What sounds are difficult for the child to say? -Does child follow directions? -Does child use gestures, such as pointing, to communicate? -Determine any complications, trauma, or illnesses during pregnancy  -Did the mother take drugs while pregnant? If so, what kind? -When did the mother deliver? -How much did the patient weigh at birth? Children with FAS typically have lower birth weight, height, and head circumference(26) -What was the APGAR score? -Were there any complications during delivery?

course of treatment.medical management: Medications commonly prescribed for patients with FAS include A combination of a stimulant and a selective serotonin receptive inhibitor (SSRI).(16) The stimulants most commonlyPaxil, Prozac, Zoloft, and Celexa(16) Clonidine is used to reduce anxiety, aggression, and hyperactivity. It is also used to relieve sleep disturbances.(16) Find out what medications are prescribed and their dosages
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: The three criteria that must be met for the diagnosis of FAS are the presence of all three facial abnormalities (i.e., smooth philtrum, thin vermillion border, and small palpebral fissures), growth deficiency, and CNS abnormality (as indicated by cognitive or developmental disability).(39,40) Prenatal alcohol exposure cannot always be confirmed; however, known or suspected exposure supports the diagnosis of FAS.(39,40) Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Often includes IQ testing such as the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children-Revised  (WISC), the Raven Colored
Progressive Matrices (CPM), and the Test of Nonverbal Intelligence (TONI2)(13,25)
Audiological evaluation: children with FAS may have a conductive or sensory hearing loss
Ophthalmology evaluation: children with FAS sometimes exhibit strabismus, ptosis, or a retinal or optic nerve abnormality
Nephrology evaluation: individuals with FAS sometimes have congenital defects impacting kidney and ureter function

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Determine if communication abilities vary with specific people and in different contexts
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Decreased expressive language and receptive language skills, recall, social skills, and attention that improves as the child ages
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physicianDocument history of psychosocial disturbance. Individuals with FAS have increased risk of depression, anxiety, hyperactivity, or attention disorders. Research on adults with FAS has found an increased risk for psychiatric disorders, legal problems, and use of illegal drugs and alcohol, indicating psychosocial difficulties(9)Review audiology testing; children with FAS have immature audiological systems, resulting in numerous ear infections, and sometimes sensorineural hearing loss(10) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Document any comorbid diagnoses. Patients with FAS have increased risk for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), learning disabilities, cardiac defects, depression, oppositional defiant disorder, obesity (especially in females), and phobias(7,37,38,44)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient/caregiver about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Does the patient use a walker, wheelchair, leg braces, or cane for ambulation? -Does the patient have hearing loss? Does the patient have a hearing aid? If so, how is it functioning? -Does the patient wear glasses? -Does the patient require assistance for feeding, bathing, and/or dressing?
social and occupational history.living environment: Document information about the patient’s living situation (e.g., stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -What is the individual’s primary language? Are there other languages that the patient uses at home or is exposed to regularly?

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (while tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting):
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: An augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) system might be appropriate depending on the severity of the child’s communication disorder. AAC includes all forms of communication, such as gestures, simple communication boards, picture boards, and writing. If a patient is difficult to understand or has very –What type of system is the patient using? –Is the system effective in all settings? –Do the caregivers or patient know how to make changes to add new information? –For detailed information on AAC, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.posture: Document any postural abnormalities that impact speech or swallowing as related the patient’s trunk or neck position
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading)Assess articulation and phonology -Obtain an estimate of speech intelligibility in structured and unstructured contexts(33)  -Analyze natural speech samples in natural contexts, particularly those indicated as areas of concern by family or teacher(33) -Use a standardized test or an informal (nonstandardized) analysis to determine articulation errors. For specific sounds, the number of omissions, substitutions, distortions, and additions can be completedLanguage impairment is common among children with FAS.(34) Children with FAS will exhibit a broad range of both expressive and receptive language deficits depending on the severity of the FAS.(27)(34) Examples of standardized language assessments include the Clinical Evaluation of Language Fundamentals (CELF), the Test of Auditory Comprehension of Language, the Test of Language Development, the Test of Language Competence, and the Test of Word Knowledge.(10,34) In addition to standardized testing, obtaining a language sample and observing the child interact with his or her peers is necessary to assess language use in everyday situations.(10) Language samples can be obtained through play and story-retelling  activities using wordless picture books. Narrative analysis is recommended so that the child’s language can be evaluated in meaningful social settings.(25) Children with FAS have demonstrated difficulty providing relevant details during conversation and narratives.(10,27) In addition, children with FAS do not take into consideration the listener’s perspective during social exchanges (i.e., pragmatic deficits)(10,19,27)Note any history of fluency disorder; for detailed information on disorders of fluency, see the series of Clinical Reviews on child-onset  fluency disorder and clutteringWhen developmentally appropriate, include a brief assessment of reading ability in the evaluation. In the school setting, the special education teacher or reading specialist will most likely be responsible for direct teaching of reading and writing skills. However, the SLP might play a support role in assessing and treating the child for reading difficulties, particularly if reading skills are needed to use AAC. Formal measures of reading or informal measures (criterion referenced) can be used
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: An oral mechanism evaluation will be needed to assess oral motor strength,How does the face appear at rest? Are the muscles symmetrical? -Thin upper lip(29) -Long, smooth philtrum(29) -Flat midface(29) -Flat nasal bridge(29) -Upturned nose(29)Assess labial retraction, protrusion, coordination of movementLabial retraction, protrusion. Are any twitching or writhing movements noted upon protrusion? Also, obtain diadochokinetic speech rates to evaluate the child’s ability to sequence sounds, if appropriate given the child’s language skillsAssess color of tissue, size. Does the patient have a prosthesis or fistula?Comment on the condition of the teeth. Are there missing teeth? Look at the patient’s bite. Does there appear to be any tongue thrusting or abnormalities that would impact speech or swallowing?
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Review neuropsychological testing to determine baseline level of functioning for cognition, including executive functioning, memory, attention, and problem solving. Research has indicated that children with FAS demonstrate deficits in all of these areas(9,13,27)
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: A swallow examination might be warranted for a child with FAS if the patient and or caregiver report any problems relating to swallowing and or feeding. If swallowing is a concern, the patient should be seen for a swallow evaluation. In a study conducted in the United States with 19 children with FASD, researchers reported thepoor appetite/“picky eater,” constant snacking, never feeling full/satisfied, and chewing problems.(37) In another study conducted in the United States, researchers synthesized data from surveys given to parents or caregivers of children with FASD (n = 74) and typically developing controls (n = 81) about eating behaviors. Researchers reported significantly more abnormal eating behaviors in the children with FASD, including delayed acquisition of self-feeding ability, impaired satiety (i.e., never feeling full), and hyperphagia.(43) For detailed information about feeding disorders and dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with FAS might be at risk for dysphagia. The patient and family must be educated regarding swallowing precautions and the safest diet for the patient. In addition to the patient, medical and educational staff members must be educated regarding appropriate diet and liquid recommendations, and any precautions that will assist the patient in swallowing safely. Education should be completed in a multimodal fashion and include a verbal discussion with written documentation

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Speech treatment for children with FAS might focus on speech, language, cognition, and/ or swallowing depending on the severity of the child’s deficits. Once the child is evaluated by an SLP, goals are determined to assist the child to improve in areas of deficit. A multidisciplinary approach is necessary to assist the patient to improve overall communication skills
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out other underlying causes of the communication disorder prior to diagnosing FAS
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: The following referrals are often necessary depending on the severity of the patient’s FAS and related deficits: Physical and occupational therapy to evaluate and treat deficits relating to mobility, ability to perform tasks related to ADLs, and/or sensory modulation deficits Audiology referral is needed to assess hearing loss and for follow-up if the patient uses a hearing aid(7) Cardiac consultation for possible heart defects(7) Nephrologist consultation for kidney problems(7) Ophthalmology to assess vision defects(7) Special education services to address developmental, educational, and behavioral difficulties that are noted(7) Referrals to psychiatry/psychology for the patient and the family to deal with depression, anxiety, or hyperactivity or attention disorders Social services will benefit the patient and family by introducing them to community services and resources
treatment summary: Authors of a systematic review found 12 studies examining interventions for children with FASD that met their inclusion criteria. Authors noted that methodological weaknesses were common (e.g., small sample sizes, poor study design, short-term  follow up). In two randomized controlled trials, there was some benefit observed from stimulant medications. In three randomized controlled trials, there was some evidence to suggest that virtual reality training, cognitive control therapy, language and literacy therapy (described below), mathematics intervention and rehearsal training for memory might be beneficial strategies. Results from three studies on social communication and behavioral strategies indicated that social skills training could improve social skills and behavior problems at home(21)

In a study conducted in South Africa with 65 children, researchers evaluated language treatment specifically for literacy skills(1) –Forty children with FAS were randomly assigned to a language literacy group or a control group. Twenty-five  children without alcohol exposure in utero were randomly selected and were assigned a control group(1) –The study did not describe the randomization method used, and selection bias cannot be ruled out(1) –The language and literacy group focused on phonological awareness and other preliteracy skills necessary for reading and spelling. An SLP administered the treatment for 30 minutes a day twice a week for nine months, totaling 36 hours of intervention(1) –Results: This intervention led to improvements in reading, spelling, and preliteracy skills for the FAS intervention group compared to the FAS control group. However, both FAS groups scored lower than the alcohol unexposed group(1)  . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Decrease hyperarousal and improve sensory modulationImprove response to various environmental stimuliTherapeutic modalities _ For children with FAS who have sensory processing deficits, the SLP might work with the occupational therapist to improve sensory integration. Examples of ways to help a child with sensory processing difficulties include using a weighted blanket, deep pressure massage, and placing the child on a swing(3)The patient responds appropriately to specific stimuli. Decreasing modeling and cueing is expected as the child’s sensory modulation improves. Educating the caregiver is important to develop effective strategies to promote learning and behavior management. Expect improved self- awareness to positively impact behavior(29)No specific home program specified. However, home practice should involve the family and relevant activities in the home environment to be determined individually Decreased attention Improve attention for all ADLsTherapeutic modalities _ Reduce number of stimuli in treatment room, reduce number of distractions _ _ Use pictures to sequence activities in a session or day _ _ Provide extensive focus on routines to facilitate attention _ _ Provide frequent salient reinforcement to promote attention _ _ Classroom modifications _ Decrease visual and auditory distractions, clearly label activity areas, use large easily visible daily schedules, organize materials so they are easy to find(20)As the child progresses, the number of stimuli can be increased. Gradually reduce support needed to promote appropriate participation by the child. Expect improved ability to participate in tasks that will positively impact behavior, social interaction, and academic progressNo specific home program is specified. However, a home program should involve the family and relevant activities in the home environment to be individually determined  Decreased pragmatic language skillsImprove pragmatic language skills, including initiation and turn takingPragmatic therapy _ Speech therapy focuses on improving initiation, turn taking, topic maintenance, and providing relevant information to the listener through clinician modeling, group therapy, use of games, and play, or simulating daily events in the patient’s life. Also, use of social scripts and role playing is helpful. Use of checklists to increase the child’s ability to assess ability to listen, evaluate consequences, and the listener’s perspective has been beneficial for improved social skills.(28)Common pragmatic difficulties for children with FAS include decreased interpretation of body language and discussing personal information that is not appropriate for the situation.(24) SLPs can assist the child to increase vocabulary to express feelings and emotions. Additionally, SLPs will work improving the child’s awareness of producing relevant statements and decreasing unrelated statements.(24) Addressing these areas will be critical to improve social interaction, especially for adolescents. Intervention is best provided in conjunction with the classroom teacher to improve communication skills in the academic setting and should include community needs as well(24)Improved social interaction is critical to promote peer interaction and improve behavior that may interfere with academic or social skillsNo specific home program is specified. However, a home program should involve the family and relevant activities in the home environment to be individually determined  Decreased expressive languageImprove expressive language skills to within functional limitsLanguage therapy _ Focuses on developmentally appropriate activities to promote expressive language skills specific to the patient’s ability level. Expressive language can be targeted through play, activities relating to daily activities, and academic needs. Therapy focusing on phonological awareness and improving preliteracy skills is critical to improve reading and spelling.(21) SLPs need to incorporate life skills, as well as academic needs. Intervention must include the classroom setting and incorporate the community. During middle school, addressing high- risk behaviors, such as alcohol and drug use, in the context of treatment is critical because children with FAS currently account for 40% of the juveniles in correctional facilities(24)Improved expressive language skills will assist the child to express wants and needs appropriately, increase learning skills and social interactionNo specific home program is specified. However, a home program should involve the family and relevant activities in the home environment to be individually determined  Decreased processing Improve auditory and visual processing to be within functional limitsClassroom accommodations _ Provide education to teachers to promote use of auditory and visual cueing as needed to assist the child. Discuss environmental changes to benefit the child’s ability to process; e.g., sitting near the teacher to best hear or visualize learning materials. Providing repetition will likely help the child in social and academic settings. Encourage the child to ask for repetition and clarification as needed and to write down key words or take notes. Use predictable routines or schedule events in the same order every day.(20) Provide extensive practice and demonstration to assist a child to perform a new task since children with FAS have difficulty learning a new skill.(20) Provide short, simple, one-step commands to increase comprehension, and break down multistep commands(20)Improved processing will assist the child to perform better in academic and social settingsNo specific home program is specified. However, a home program should involve the family and relevant activities in the home environment to be individually determined  Decreased recall Improve recall to be within functional limits for daily needsFunctional training _ Educate the patient and family regarding compensatory strategies such as using lists, timers, verbal rehearsal, and calendars to remember appointments or daily tasks. Research indicates that children with FAS might not be able to use strategies correctly and/or consistently.(22)Giving simple instructions on how to use these strategies is essential, as is monitoring appropriate use of these strategies(22)Improved recall will assist the child to perform better in social and academic settingsNo specific home program is specified. However, a home program should involve the family and relevant activities in the home environment to be individually determined Decreased speech intelligibilityImprove speech intelligibility to be within functional limits.The SLP will target specific sounds or phonological processes based on assessment results. These sounds or processes will be targeted through play activities and drill-type activities that will yield a high number of repetitions of the correct sound to promote improved speech. Also, shaping activities may be used to assist a patient to achieve improved articulation. For detailed information on articulation assessment and intervention, please see Clinical Review…Speech Sound Disorders: Articulation Disorder, Organic ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708924Improved speech intelligibility will assist the child to communicate more effectively and will promote improved peer interaction and participation in social and academic activitiesNo specific home program is specified. However, a home program should involve the family and relevant activities in the home environment to be individually determined .

improved speech intelligibility: Standardized or informal measures of articulation
increased receptive and expressive langu: Test of Auditory Comprehension of Language
improved pragmatic language abilities: Number of appropriate turn-taking  moments in conversation
improved reading abilities: Standardized or informal measures of reading

maintenance or prevention: FAS is the most preventable cause of intellectual disability; however, prevention of FAS is still complex.(5,35) Providing education about safe alcohol drinking practices during pregnancy to non-pregnant  women who are of child-bearing  age, as well as pregnant women, is essential to reducing the risk of FAS.(5,41,46) In addition, early identification of deficits is critical to assist the infant, toddler, or child with developmental delays through early-intervention  programs.(35)Children who are at high risk for FAS (e.g., those in the child welfare system) should be screened regularly for FAS so they can be accurately diagnosed and receive appropriate intervention(35)

A maintenance program should be developed and should include training and education of the patient and family members. In addition to family members, other relevant people might be involved, including teachers, mentors, and supervisors. Reevaluation is important to assess any change in status and should be completed as appropriate.
patient education: See http://www.nofas.org/parents/  for more information about FAS and resources to assist the patient, family, and care providers
See http://www.nofas.org/about/  for information for educators working with children with FAS Note

Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on February 3, 2017 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
